docs.title: An open-source, shoe-agnostic, 3D-printable ankle exoskeleton for accessible locomotion research
docs.text: 📄 Paper Abstract (click to expand)  Wearable ankle exoskeletons are a key testbed for assistive control and human-robot interaction during locomotion, but many systems remain difficult to build and deploy due to fabrication and fitting overhead (e.g., CNC/composite processes, long lead times, and shoe-specific interfaces).  We present PrintExo, an open-source, shoe-agnostic, fully 3D-printable ankle exoskeleton platform designed to lower the barrier to early-stage locomotion research and rapid prototyping. PrintExo can be fabricated using consumer-grade FDM printing and standard off-the-shelf components, and integrates a compact 3D-printed 1:4 planetary gearbox for ankle assistance (total assembled mass: 1.33 kg per leg, excluding the user’s shoe).  A lace-anchored shoe interface transmits torque through commercially available lace-up footwear without permanent modification, enabling fast fitting across participants.  The device was evaluated in a pilot treadmill study with five able-bodied participants walking at 1.0 m/s under three conditions: no-device, zero-torque, and powered assistance. Across completed sessions, powered assistance reduced metabolic cost relative to zero-torque, and encoder-derived kinematics captured device-side ankle motion during torque application.  Overall, PrintExo provides a practical, low-overhead, open-source platform for accessible ankle-exoskeleton prototyping and pilot locomotion experiments.

docs.title: ⭐️ Key Features
docs.text:
• Fully 3D-printable structure using consumer-grade FDM printers
  • Shoe-agnostic, lace-anchored interface with no permanent footwear modification
  • Off-the-shelf hardware only, no custom machining
  • Modular design for rapid prototyping and experimentation
  • Open CAD and build documentation for reproducible use

docs.title: 📦 Open Resources
docs.text:
• 🔗 CAD, STL, and G-code
  • 🔗 Assembly manual
  • 🔗 Example Control demo scripts — coming soon
  • 🔗 Research paper — coming soon

All resources will be released in a public repository.

docs.title: ⚠️ Disclaimer
docs.text: PrintExo is a prototype research platform intended for pilot studies and educational use. It is not a certified medical device, and its safety or clinical effectiveness has not been established. PrintExo should not be used for diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, or unsupervised human assistance. All experiments involving human subjects should follow your local Institutional Review Board (IRB) or equivalent ethics approval process.

docs.title: 📑 Citation
docs.text:
If you use PrintExo in your work, please cite:

@unpublished{baek2026printexo,
  author = {Baek, Sunin and Lee, Yuhyun and Hur, Benjamin and Cha, Eun Sang and Kim, Daekyum},
  title  = {PrintExo: An Open-Source, Shoe-Agnostic, 3D-Printable Ankle Exoskeleton for Accessible Locomotion Research},
  note   = {Manuscript submitted to IEEE RAS/EMBS International Conference on Biomedical Robotics and Biomechatronics (BioRob)},
  year   = {2026}
}

docs.title: About PrintExo
docs.text: PrintExo is an open-source, shoe-agnostic, 3D-printable ankle exoskeleton developed by the Movement Intelligence Laboratory (MINT Lab) at Korea University.

docs.text:

  • Accessible documentation — comprehensive guides for all skill levels
  • Community-driven — contributions and feedback welcome

docs.title: What is PrintExo?
docs.text: PrintExo is an open-source, 3D-printable ankle exoskeleton designed to lower the barriers to wearable robotics research and education. It uses consumer-grade FDM printers and standard off-the-shelf components.

docs.title: Who developed PrintExo?
docs.text: PrintExo was developed by the Movement Intelligence Laboratory (MINT Lab) at Korea University.

docs.title: Is PrintExo free to use?
docs.text: Yes. PrintExo is open-source. All CAD files, documentation, and software are freely available.

docs.title: What 3D printer do I need?
docs.text: Any consumer-grade FDM 3D printer. We recommend the Bambu Lab X1C, but other printers work as well.

docs.title: What material should I use?
docs.text: PLA is recommended for ease of printing. PETG or carbon-fiber–reinforced filaments are also compatible for improved durability.

docs.title: How long does it take to print all parts?
docs.text: Approximately 2 days per leg (1 day 23 hours 51 minutes) with 70% gyroid infill and supports.

docs.title: How much filament do I need?
docs.text: About 950 g per leg (model + supports).

docs.title: What motor does PrintExo use?
docs.text: CubeMars AK60-6 V1.1 KV140 actuator with integrated driver.

docs.title: What tools do I need?
docs.text:
• Hex key set (2.5 mm for M3)
  • Screwdriver
  • Drill bits (2.5 mm, 3.0 mm)
  • M3 hand tap
  • Calipers
  • Needle-nose pliers

docs.title: How long does assembly take?
docs.text: Approximately 2–4 hours for a first-time builder, less with experience.

docs.title: Do I need special skills?
docs.text: Basic mechanical assembly skills are sufficient. No machining or specialized equipment required.

docs.title: What shoes can I use with PrintExo?
docs.text: Any lace-up shoe. The shoe interface is designed to be shoe-agnostic and attaches through standard shoelaces.

docs.title: Is PrintExo safe to wear?
docs.text: PrintExo is a research platform. Always perform bench testing before human trials, start with zero-torque mode, and follow all safety guidelines in the documentation.

docs.title: Can I modify the design?
docs.text: Yes. Editable CAD files (.f3d) are provided. We encourage modifications and improvements.

docs.title: Where can I find solutions to common problems?
docs.text: See the Troubleshooting section for hardware, assembly, and electronics issues.

docs.title: My question isn't answered here. What should I do?
docs.text:
• Check the Troubleshooting section
  • Review the documentation for your specific issue
  • Contact the development team
  • Open an issue on GitHub

docs.title: Electronics & Control
docs.text:
This section will be updated in future releases to provide example electronics and control implementations used with PrintExo.

The content is intended as a reference use case, rather than a prescriptive or required control setup. Alternative electronics configurations and control strategies may be used depending on research goals.

Planned example topics include:

  • electronics overview
  • motor driver setup and configuration
  • control software structure
  • running a full walking demo

Details will be added as example implementations are documented.

docs.title: Build the Robot
docs.text:
This section walks you through how to physically build PrintExo — from parts sourcing to 3D printing and final assembly.

PrintExo is designed to be: - FDM-printable using consumer desktop 3D printers, - off-the-shelf friendly with standard, easily sourced hardware, - shoe-agnostic, requiring no permanent modification to footwear.

docs.title: Build pipeline
docs.text:
1. Bill of Materials (BOM) – what to buy
  2. 3D Printing Guide – what to print and recommended settings
  3. Assembly Guide & Shoelace Fixation Guide – step-by-step build and fitting

docs.title: Start here
docs.text:
• Bill of Materials (BOM)
  • 3D Printing Guide
  • Assembly Guide
  • Shoelace Fixation Guide

Note: PrintExo consists of an actuation unit, a shank structure, and a lace-anchored shoe interface. Detailed design and implementation instructions are provided in the pages above.

docs.title: Assembly Guide
docs.text: This guide describes how to assemble PrintExo from 3D-printed components, off-the-shelf mechanical parts, and electronics.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
PrintExo uses a modular architecture organized into three main subsystems:

Subsystem Description Actuation module Motor, planetary gear stage, protective casing Shank structure Vertical frame, passive hinge, calf attachment Shoe interface Dorsal component, plantar guides, lace integration

Assembly follows a bottom-up approach: gearbox → actuation module → shank → shoe interface.

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] All 3D-printed parts completed and post-processed
  • [ ] All BOM components available (bearings, fasteners, motor)
  • [ ] Required tools prepared
  • [ ] Clean, well-lit workspace

docs.title: Recommended Preparation
docs.text:
1. Verify printed parts — check for warping, incomplete features, or layer defects
  2. Ream all holes — use appropriate drill bits to clean up M3 holes
  3. Tap threads — tap M3 holes where bolts will be inserted
  4. Dry-fit bearings — ensure press-fit is snug but not cracked

docs.title: 3. Required Tools
docs.text: Tool Size/Spec Purpose Hex key set 2.5 mm (for M3) Tightening bolts Screwdriver Phillips / Flat General fastening Drill bits 2.5 mm, 3.0 mm Hole reaming Hand tap M3 × 0.5 Threading holes Needle-nose pliers — Support removal, small parts Calipers — Dimensional verification Power drill (optional) — Speeds up drilling/tapping

docs.title: Step 1 — Sun Gear Assembly
docs.text: Fit the Sun Gear to the Sun Gear Holder.

docs.title: Step 2 — Align Screw Holes
docs.text: Align the screw holes.

docs.title: Step 3 — Fasten Sun Gear
docs.text: Fasten using six (6) M3 × 22 mm screws until each screw contacts the bottom surface.

docs.title: Step 4 — Mount Sun Gear to Actuation Module
docs.text:
Align the Sun Gear with the six (6) screw holes on the Actuation Module (CubeMars AK60-6 V1.1 KV140). Fasten in the specified order, then tighten fully.

⚠️ Caution: Do not let any screw tilt the Sun Gear contact surface.

docs.title: Step 5 — Planet Gear Bearing Installation
docs.text: Insert one (1) HK0810 (8×12×10) into each of the four (4) Planet Gears.

docs.title: Step 6 — Ring Gear Installation
docs.text: Align the Ring Gear with the Actuation Module, then insert it fully.

docs.title: Step 7 — Secure Ring Gear
docs.text: Fasten using six (6) M3 × 5 mm screws in the specified order, then tighten fully.

docs.title: Step 8 — Carrier Bearing Installation
docs.text: Insert one (1) HK0810 (8×12×10) into the Carrier.

docs.title: Step 9 — Medial Gearbox Bracket
docs.text: Align the Medial Gearbox Bracket with the bearing, then insert it fully.

docs.title: Step 10 — Planet Gears Installation
docs.text: Align the four (4) Planet Gears with the bearings, then insert them fully.

docs.title: Step 11 — Sun Gear Engagement
docs.text:
Align the Actuation Module Sun Gear with the bearing, then insert it fully.

⚠️ Caution: Align the teeth of the four (4) Planet Gears with the teeth of the Sun Gear.

docs.title: Step 12 — Carrier Fastening
docs.text: Insert M3 flat washers, then fasten the Carrier to the Actuation Module using two (2) M3 × 22 mm screws. Tighten fully.

docs.title: Step 13 — Medial Cover
docs.text: Fasten the Medial Cover using three (3) M3 × 22 mm screws. Tighten fully.

docs.title: Step 14 — Lower Bracket
docs.text: Fasten the Lower Bracket using three (3) M3 × 22 mm screws. Tighten fully.

docs.title: Step 15 — Check Assembly
docs.text: Check that there are no gaps between modules.

docs.title: Step 16 — Passive Hinge Bearings
docs.text: Insert two (2) HK0810 (8×12×10) into the holes in the Passive Hinge section of the Shank Structure.

docs.title: Step 17 — Shank Structure & Hinge Pin
docs.text: Fit the Shank Structure to the Ring Gear. Insert the Hinge Pin, then fasten using one (1) M3 × 40 mm screw. Tighten fully.

docs.title: Step 18 — Upper Bracket to Hinge Pin
docs.text: Fasten the Upper Bracket to the Hinge Pin using one (1) M3 × 40 mm screw. Tighten fully.

docs.title: Step 19 — Upper Bracket to Ring Gear
docs.text: Fasten the Upper Bracket to the Ring Gear using three (3) M3 × 22 mm screws. Tighten fully.

docs.title: Step 20 — Calf Compression Sleeve & Strap Anchor
docs.text:
Fasten the Calf Compression Sleeve and Strap Anchor to the Shank Structure using four (4) M3 × 22 mm screws. Tighten fully.

⚠️ Caution: Select the size option based on the user's shank length, then fasten through the corresponding holes.

docs.title: Step 21 — Wire Guide
docs.text: Fasten the Wire Guide using four (4) M3 × 22 mm screws. Tighten fully.

docs.title: Step 22 — Dorsal Interface
docs.text:
Fasten the shoe-mounted Dorsal Interface to the Carrier using four (4) M3 × 20 mm screws. Tighten fully.

ℹ️ Note: This step attaches the dorsal interface to the device. Instructions for mounting the dorsal interface onto the shoe are provided in the Shoelace Fixation Guide.

docs.title: Step 23 — Auxiliary Lace
docs.text:
Use the Auxiliary Lace to secure the Dorsal Interface and Carrier assembly to the shoe.

ℹ️ Note: Detailed lace routing and tying instructions are provided in the Shoelace Fixation Guide.

docs.title: Step 24 — Complete 🎉
docs.text: Assembly complete.

docs.title: 5. Alignment & Fit Verification
docs.text: After assembly, perform the following checks:

docs.title: Mechanical Checks
docs.text: Check Expected Result Gearbox rotation Smooth, no grinding or binding Hinge movement Free inversion/eversion motion Motor operation Spins without obstruction Shoe interface rigidity No wobble at mounting point

docs.title: Fit Checks
docs.text:
• [ ] Shank aligned with lateral side of lower leg
  • [ ] Ankle joint axis approximately aligned with device axis
  • [ ] Calf sleeve secure while comfortable
  • [ ] Laces tensioned evenly across dorsal interface
  • [ ] No pinch points during range of motion test

docs.title: 6. Safety Notes
docs.text:
• Do not over-tighten M3 bolts — PLA can crack under excessive torque
  • Inspect all structural joints before human testing
  • Check for pinch points around hinge and gearbox

docs.title: Bill of Materials (BOM)
docs.text: This page lists all non-printed components and printing consumables required to build one PrintExo unit. All custom structural parts are fabricated using 3D printing and are documented separately in the 3D Printing Guide.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
PrintExo is designed to minimize sourcing complexity by: - relying on standard, off-the-shelf components, - avoiding custom machining or proprietary parts, and - enabling regional substitution where possible.

The total hardware cost (excluding tools and the 3D printer) is approximately $359 per leg.

All listed components can be sourced from common online retailers or local suppliers.

All costs in this BOM are listed in U.S. dollars (USD).

docs.title: 2. Printing Consumables
docs.text:
3D-printed parts are not listed individually in this BOM. Instead, printing requirements are summarized as consumables.

Item Specification Qty Unit Cost Example Source Notes P01 PLA filament (1.0 kg) 2 $19.99 Bambu Store Any standard PLA filament is acceptable

Note: Detailed part lists, orientations, and print settings are provided in the 3D Printing Guide.

docs.title: 3. Fasteners & Bearings
docs.text:
Item Specification Qty Unit Cost Example Source Notes H01 M3 bolt, 5 mm 12 $0.05 MiSUMi H02 M3 bolt, 12 mm 8 $0.05 MiSUMi H03 M3 bolt, 18 mm 6 $0.05 MiSUMi H04 M3 bolt, 20 mm 8 $0.05 MiSUMi H05 M3 bolt, 22 mm 48 $0.05 MiSUMi H06 M3 bolt, 40 mm 4 $0.05 MiSUMi H07 Bearing (HK0810) 8 $2.71 MiSUMi H08 M3 plastic washer (spacer) 2 $0.42 MiSUMi

Note: Unit costs are approximate, normalized estimates for budgeting consistency; actual prices vary by supplier and purchase volume.

docs.title: 4. Actuator
docs.text:
Item Specification Qty Unit Cost Example Source Notes A01 CubeMars AK60-6 V1.1 KV140 2 $ 298.90 CubeMars One per leg, integrated driver

Note: This BOM covers the exoskeleton hardware platform; electrical design and power supply configurations may vary by use case, so only the actuator is specified here.

docs.title: 5. Etcs
docs.text: Item Specification Qty Unit Cost Example Source Notes E01 Calf compression sleeve 2 $ 16.99 Amazon One per leg E02 Shoe laces (auxiliary) 2 $ 10.00 Amazon

docs.title: 6. Tools Required (Non-consumable)
docs.text:
The following tools are commonly required for assembly but are not included in the BOM cost.

Tool Notes Hex key set M3 fasteners Screwdrivers General assembly Hand drill Hole cleanup / tapping M3 tap Recommended Flush cutters Support removal

docs.title: 7. Substitutions & Alternatives
docs.text:
• Fasteners and bearings: Equivalent metric components may be substituted if dimensions match.

  • Filament: PETG or carbon-fiber–reinforced filaments are compatible but may require print setting adjustments.

When deviating from the reference configuration, verify mechanical fit and electrical compatibility.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• 3D Printing Guide
  • Assembly Guide

docs.title: 3D Printing Guide
docs.text: This page provides detailed instructions for 3D printing all custom structural components of PrintExo.

docs.title: CAD Files
docs.text:
All CAD files required for 3D printing PrintExo are provided as open-source resources.

  • Printable STL files for all structural components
  • Editable Fusion 360 parametric models (.f3d)
  • Optional parametric export script for shoe-width customization

👉 Download CAD files: Google Drive – PrintExo CAD Release

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
Key points:

  • All custom parts are designed for consumer-grade FDM printers
  • Primary material: PLA (PETG or carbon-fiber–reinforced filaments also compatible)

The following subsystems require 3D-printed components:

Subsystem Components Actuation module Planetary gear stage, protective casing Shank structure Shank body, passive hinge Shoe interface Dorsal component, plantar guides

docs.title: Printing Estimates (per leg)
docs.text:
Item Value Total print time 1 day 23 hours 51 minutes Model filament 928.70 g Support filament 21.22 g Total filament 949.92 g Estimated cost $23.74

Note: Estimates based on 70% gyroid infill with supports. Actual values may vary depending on printer, slicer settings, and filament brand.

docs.title: Printer
docs.text:
• Recommended: Bambu Lab X1C (or equivalent enclosed FDM printer)
  • Any consumer-grade FDM 3D printer is compatible

docs.title: Nozzle
docs.text:
• Diameter: 0.4 mm (standard)
  • Hardened steel nozzle recommended for abrasive filaments

docs.title: Slicer Software
docs.text:
• Bambu Studio (for Bambu Lab printers)
  • PrusaSlicer, Cura, or equivalent

docs.title: Optional
docs.text:
• Filament dryer (recommended for hygroscopic materials like PETG)
  • Enclosed chamber (improves print consistency)

docs.title: 3. General Print Settings
docs.text: Parameter Recommended Value Notes Layer height 0.20 mm Balance between speed and strength Nozzle diameter 0.4 mm Standard Infill pattern Gyroid Good omnidirectional strength Infill ratio 70% For structural rigidity Perimeters (walls) 4 Increases shell strength Top/Bottom layers 5 Ensures solid surfaces Support Part-dependent See Part-by-Part notes Material PLA PETG or CF-PLA also compatible Bed temperature 60°C For PLA Nozzle temperature 210°C Adjust per filament brand

docs.title: 4. Print Orientation & Strength Considerations
docs.text: FDM prints exhibit anisotropic strength — they are weakest along the layer lines (Z-axis).

docs.title: Guidelines
docs.text:
1. Load-bearing parts should be oriented so that primary stresses act parallel to the print bed (X-Y plane), not perpendicular (Z-axis).

  2. Planetary gears require careful orientation to ensure tooth strength and smooth meshing.

  3. Use brims (5–10 mm) for parts with small footprints to prevent warping and improve bed adhesion.

  4. Avoid rafts unless absolutely necessary — they can affect dimensional accuracy on mating surfaces.

docs.title: Critical Orientations
docs.text: Part Recommended Orientation Reason Shank body Vertical (standing) Maximizes bending strength Gear components Flat (teeth facing up) Preserves tooth geometry Shoe interface Flat Ensures accurate mounting surfaces

docs.title: 5. Part-by-Part Printing Notes
docs.text:
Part Name Quantity Orientation Support Infill Special Notes Sun gear 1 Flat No 70% — Planet gear 3 Flat No 70% Print bearings separately Ring gear 1 Flat No 70% Check inner teeth quality Carrier 1 Flat Yes 70% Remove supports carefully Motor casing 1 Upright Yes 50% — Shank body 1 Vertical Yes 70% Orient for bending load Hinge component 2 Flat No 70% — Dorsal interface 1 Flat Yes 70% Size-specific Plantar guide 2 Flat No 50% —

Note: This table is an example. Refer to the CAD files for the complete part list.

docs.title: 6. Post-processing
docs.text: After printing, perform the following steps:

docs.title: 6.1 Support Removal
docs.text:
• Use flush cutters or needle-nose pliers
  • Be careful around gear teeth and mounting holes

docs.title: 6.2 Surface Finishing
docs.text:
• Light sanding (220–400 grit) on mating surfaces
  • Focus on surfaces that interface with bearings or fasteners

docs.title: 6.3 Hole Preparation
docs.text:
• Reaming: Use appropriately sized drill bits to clean up holes
  • Tapping: M3 holes may require tapping for secure bolt threads

docs.title: 6.4 Dimensional Verification
docs.text:
• Check critical dimensions with calipers
  • Gear mesh should be smooth without binding
  • Bearing press-fit should be snug but not overly tight

docs.title: 7. Common Printing Issues
docs.text: Issue Possible Cause Solution Warping Poor bed adhesion, no enclosure Use brim, increase bed temp, use enclosure Layer delamination Under-extrusion, low temp Increase nozzle temp, check filament quality Poor gear tooth finish Too fast, insufficient cooling Reduce speed for outer walls, increase cooling Holes too tight Over-extrusion Calibrate flow rate, or ream holes after printing Holes too loose Under-extrusion Increase flow rate, or use smaller drill bit Stringing High temp, no retraction Lower temp, enable/increase retraction Z-seam visible Slicer settings Set seam position to "sharpest corner" or "rear"

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After completing all prints and post-processing:

  • Assembly Guide — Step-by-step assembly instructions

docs.title: Having Issues?
docs.text: • Troubleshooting — Hardware Issues — Print quality and fit problems

docs.title: Shoelace Fixation Guide
docs.text: This guide describes how to mount the dorsal interface onto the shoe and secure it using auxiliary shoelaces for PrintExo.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
The shoelace fixation method provides a non-invasive, shoe-agnostic interface that allows PrintExo to be mounted on standard lace-up footwear without permanent modification.

This guide covers: - mounting the dorsal interface onto the shoe, - routing and tensioning shoelaces for secure fixation.

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] PrintExo assembly completed up to Assembly Guide – Step 21
  • [ ] Dorsal interface prepared
  • [ ] Auxiliary shoelaces prepared
  • [ ] Lace-up shoe selected (standard eyelets)

docs.title: Step 1 — Prepare the Shoe
docs.text: Loosen and remove the original shoelaces to expose the shoe tongue.

docs.title: Step 2 — Position the Dorsal Interface
docs.text: Place the Dorsal Interface on top of the shoe tongue and align it with the shoe eyelets.

docs.title: Step 3 — Route the Shoelace
docs.text: Route the shoelace in the following order as shown.

docs.title: Step 4 — Wear the Shoe and Adjust Lace Tension
docs.text: Put on the shoe and adjust the shoelace tension evenly for comfort and stability.

docs.title: Step 5 — Fasten the Carrier to the Dorsal Interface
docs.text: This step is identical to Step 22 of the Assembly Guide. For clarity, only the Carrier is shown here; the rest of the PrintExo assembly is omitted.

docs.title: Step 6 — (Optional) Secure the Remaining Shoelace to the Carrier
Step 7 — Wear the Shoe and Adjust for Fit
Step 1 — Prepare the Auxiliary Shoelace and Shoe
docs.text: Prepare the auxiliary shoelace and the shoe with the carrier already attached.

docs.title: Step 2 — Center the Auxiliary Shoelace
docs.text: Place the auxiliary shoelace at its midpoint, as shown.

docs.title: Step 3 — Route the Auxiliary Shoelace
docs.text: Route the auxiliary shoelace in the order shown below.

docs.title: Step 4 — Wear the Shoe and Adjust Lace Tension
docs.text: Put on the shoe and adjust the auxiliary shoelace tension evenly.

docs.title: Step 5 — Tie the Remaining Shoelace
docs.text: Tie the remaining shoelace as shown below. This is one example; alternative knots may also be used.

docs.title: 5. Next Steps
docs.text:
After completing shoelace fixation, return to the assembly workflow:

  • Assembly Guide
  • Alignment & Fit Verification

docs.title: Workshop / Course
docs.text:
This section is intended for course and workshop materials built around PrintExo.

It can be used for:

  • undergraduate / graduate classes
  • short hands-on workshops
  • lab training sessions
  • self-paced learning modules

docs.title: 📚 Planned Lesson Structure (Placeholder)
docs.text:
The lesson sequence is tentatively:

  1. Introduction to PrintExo and wearable robotics
  2. 3D printing concepts and fabrication workflow
  3. Mechanical assembly
  4. Electronics and control basics
  5. Walking demonstration and evaluation
  6. Final project or open-ended design extension

✏️ Only this index page exists for now. Individual lesson pages will be added later.

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Objectives (Placeholder)
docs.text:
By completing the course, participants should be able to:

  • explain the principles of ankle exoskeletons
  • fabricate and assemble PrintExo
  • configure electronics and motor control
  • run a walking demonstration
  • discuss limitations and future research directions

docs.title: 🛠 How to Use This Section
docs.text:
You may later include:

  • lecture slides
  • lab handouts
  • datasets
  • assignment descriptions
  • instructor notes

docs.title: 🚧 Status
docs.text: This section is under development and will be expanded as educational materials are created.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This page explains how to navigate the PrintExo documentation and where to begin depending on your goal.

docs.title: Documentation Structure
docs.text:
The documentation is organized into the following sections:

  • Build the Robot fabrication, hardware, and mechanical assembly

  • Electronics & Control — coming soon example electronics setups and reference control pipelines

  • Troubleshooting — coming soon common build and operation issues

  • Paper & Citation research background and academic reference

docs.title: If you want to build the device
docs.text:
1. Bill of Materials (BOM)
  2. 3D Printing Guide
  3. Assembly Guide
  4. Shoelace Fixation Guide

docs.title: If you want example electronics or control
docs.text: Refer to Electronics & Control for reference implementations. These examples are not prescriptive and may be adapted or replaced.

docs.title: If you are using PrintExo for research
docs.text:
See:

  • Build the Robot — Overview
  • Paper & Citation

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Most users should start with:

Build the Robot → Bill of Materials (BOM)

and proceed step-by-step through the build guides.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
This section will be expanded in future releases as common build and operation issues are identified through community use.

At this stage, troubleshooting guidance is intentionally minimal to prioritize: - independent replication, - real-world usage feedback, - and direct communication during early adoption.

docs.title: Contact
docs.text:
If you encounter issues while building or operating PrintExo, please contact the author with a brief description of the problem.

Including photos, short videos, and relevant build details is highly encouraged.

Sunin Baek MINT Lab, School of Mechanical Engineering, Korea University 📧 suninbaek@korea.ac.kr

docs.title: Troubleshooting — Assembly Issues
docs.text: This page provides solutions for common problems encountered during PrintExo assembly.

docs.title: Incorrect Part Orientation
docs.text: Symptom Cause Solution Parts don't mate Flipped or rotated incorrectly Check CAD reference, reassemble Asymmetric fit Left/right parts swapped Verify part labels, reinstall correctly Holes don't align Part upside down Disassemble and flip part

docs.title: Missing Components
docs.text:
Issue Checklist Spacers missing Verify BOM, check packaging Washers missing Use BOM checklist before assembly Bearings forgotten Disassemble and install before continuing

Tip: Lay out all parts and cross-check with BOM before starting assembly.

docs.title: Screws Not Aligning with Holes
docs.text: Cause Solution Print warping Reprint affected part with brim Wrong screw length Verify screw spec against BOM Hole not drilled/tapped Ream and tap before assembly Parts shifted during tightening Loosen all screws, realign, retighten evenly

docs.title: Planet Gears Not Rotating Freely
docs.text: Cause Solution Bearing not seated Press bearing fully into housing Debris in bearing Clean with compressed air Bearing seized Replace bearing Gear teeth binding Check sun gear centering

docs.title: Sun Gear Misalignment
docs.text:
Symptom Cause Solution Uneven rotation resistance Sun gear off-center Use planet gears to verify centering (see Assembly Guide) Clicking during rotation Partial tooth engagement Reassemble with proper alignment Premature wear Continuous off-axis loading Disassemble, inspect, realign

Caution: Even slight misalignment causes binding, uneven wear, or gear failure. Always verify centering before installing ring gear.

docs.title: Ring Gear Installation Problems
docs.text: Issue Cause Solution Won't seat fully Planet gears mispositioned Rotate planets to align with ring gear teeth Tight fit Print tolerance Lightly sand ring gear outer surface Loose fit Oversized housing Use shim or retaining compound

docs.title: Stripped Threads
docs.text: Cause Solution Over-tightening Reprint part, use thread insert (heat-set) Cross-threading Back out, realign, restart carefully Repeated assembly/disassembly Install brass thread inserts

docs.title: Over-Tightened Bolts
docs.text:
Symptom Result Solution Bolt won't turn Threads seized Apply heat carefully, back out slowly Part cracked Excessive torque Reprint part, use lower torque Head stripped Wrong tool size Use correct hex key, replace bolt

Prevention: Tighten until snug, then 1/4 turn more. PLA does not require high torque.

docs.title: Cross-Threading
docs.text: Symptom Solution Bolt goes in crooked Back out completely, realign, restart Resistance increases suddenly Stop immediately, check alignment Threads damaged Re-tap hole, or reprint part

docs.title: Bolt Length Issues
docs.text: Issue Cause Solution Bolt too short Wrong spec Check BOM, use correct length Bolt too long Bottoming out Add washer, or use correct length Bolt protrudes dangerously Incorrect part stackup Verify assembly order

docs.title: Bearing Won't Press In
docs.text: Cause Solution Hole undersized Ream carefully with appropriate bit Bearing cocked Align squarely, press evenly Debris in hole Clean hole before installation

docs.title: Bearing Falls Out
docs.text: Cause Solution Hole oversized Use retaining compound (Loctite 648) Housing cracked Reprint part Wrong bearing size Verify bearing spec against BOM

docs.title: Bearing Doesn't Spin Freely
docs.text: Cause Solution Over-pressed Bearing deformed — replace Contamination Clean with isopropyl alcohol Wrong bearing type Verify bearing spec (must be appropriate type)

docs.title: 5. Post-Assembly Functional Checks
docs.text: Perform these checks after completing assembly:

docs.title: Gearbox Rotation Test
docs.text: Check Expected If Failed Rotate output by hand Smooth, consistent resistance Check gear alignment, bearing seating Full 360° rotation No binding at any position Look for debris, check tooth mesh Backdrive input Should rotate with gear ratio resistance Verify all gears engaged

docs.title: Hinge Alignment Test
docs.text: Check Expected If Failed Inversion motion Free movement, no binding Check hinge pin, clear debris Eversion motion Free movement, no binding Verify hinge components aligned Return to neutral Smooth return Check for friction, misalignment

docs.title: Shank-to-Actuator Connection
docs.text: Check Expected If Failed No wobble Rigid connection Tighten fasteners, check mating surfaces Aligned with output Straight torque transmission Reassemble with proper alignment

docs.title: Shoe Interface Check
docs.text: Check Expected If Failed Rigid mounting No play at connection point Tighten bolts, verify fit Lace tension Even across all guides Relace following guide pattern Plantar guides secure No looseness Verify installation

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Troubleshooting — Hardware Issues
  • Assembly Guide
  • 3D Printing Guide

docs.title: Troubleshooting — Electronics & Control Issues
docs.text: ⚡ Note: This page is a placeholder. Add real debugging procedures once the control stack is finalized.

docs.title: 1. Power Issues
docs.text:
Possible placeholder categories:

  • system will not power on
  • voltage drop under load
  • overheating power components

docs.title: 2. Motor Driver Problems
docs.text:
To fill in later:

  • motor not detected
  • motor turns in wrong direction
  • encoder not reading
  • overcurrent or fault state

docs.title: 3. Communication Errors
docs.text:
Examples:

  • CAN / UART not responding
  • intermittent packet loss
  • latency affecting control timing

docs.title: 4. Sensor / IMU Issues
docs.text:
Add test procedures later for:

  • gait phase estimation instability
  • missing IMU data
  • incorrect orientation estimation

docs.title: 5. Control Software Issues
docs.text:
Placeholders for:

  • controller not running
  • startup exceptions
  • torque command instability

✏️ Replace placeholders with logs, screenshots, and recommended fixes when available.

docs.title: Troubleshooting — Hardware Issues
docs.text: This page provides solutions for common mechanical and hardware problems encountered when building or using PrintExo.

docs.title: Parts Do Not Fit Together
docs.text: Symptom Possible Cause Solution Parts too tight Over-extrusion, elephant's foot Sand mating surfaces, calibrate flow rate Parts too loose Under-extrusion, shrinkage Reprint with adjusted settings, use shims Misaligned holes Print warping, incorrect orientation Reprint with brim, verify print orientation

docs.title: Holes Too Tight or Too Loose
docs.text: Issue Cause Solution M3 bolt won't thread Hole undersized or filled with stringing Ream with 2.5 mm drill, tap with M3 tap Bolt spins freely Hole oversized, stripped threads Use thread-locking compound, reprint part Bearing won't press in Hole undersized Ream carefully, avoid cracking Bearing falls out Hole oversized Use retaining compound (Loctite 648)

docs.title: Interference Between Moving Parts
docs.text:
• Check for: Residual support material, stringing, over-extrusion blobs
  • Solution: Carefully trim with flush cutters, sand contact surfaces
  • Prevention: Increase clearance in CAD, improve print cooling

docs.title: Excessive Backlash
docs.text: Cause Solution Worn gear teeth Inspect and reprint affected gears Loose bearing fit Replace bearings, check housing dimensions Sun gear not centered Reassemble with proper alignment (see Assembly Guide)

docs.title: Unusual Noise (Grinding, Clicking)
docs.text: Noise Type Likely Cause Solution Grinding Gear teeth interference, debris Disassemble, clean, check tooth mesh Clicking Chipped tooth, foreign object Inspect teeth, remove debris Whining Tight mesh, insufficient lubrication Verify clearances, apply light grease

docs.title: Jamming During Rotation
docs.text:
1. Check sun gear centering — misalignment causes binding
  2. Inspect planet gear bearings — seized bearings lock rotation
  3. Verify ring gear alignment — ensure it's seated properly
  4. Look for debris — plastic shavings can jam teeth

docs.title: Cracked Printed Parts
docs.text: Location Likely Cause Solution Around bolt holes Over-tightening Reprint, use torque-limiting technique Layer lines Weak layer adhesion Reprint with higher temp, slower speed Stress concentration Design issue Reinforce with epoxy, report for CAD update

docs.title: Layer Delamination
docs.text: Cause Solution Low nozzle temperature Increase temp by 5–10°C Fast print speed Reduce speed for structural parts Moisture in filament Dry filament before printing Poor bed adhesion (warping stress) Use enclosure, increase bed temp

docs.title: Deformed Components
docs.text: Symptom Cause Solution Warped flat surfaces Heat, inadequate cooling Reprint with better cooling, use enclosure Bent shank Overload during use Inspect for cracks, reprint if compromised Sagging overhangs Insufficient support Reprint with supports enabled

docs.title: Calf Sleeve Slipping
docs.text: Cause Solution Sleeve too loose Use smaller size or add padding Smooth sleeve material Add silicone grip strips Excessive sweating Use moisture-wicking liner

docs.title: Lace Interface Loosening
docs.text: Symptom Cause Solution Interface shifts during walking Laces not tight enough Re-tension laces, double-knot Laces slip through guides Worn guide edges Inspect guides, reprint if damaged Uneven tension Improper lacing pattern Follow lacing guide in Assembly section

docs.title: Discomfort or Pressure Points
docs.text: Location Cause Solution Top of foot Dorsal interface too rigid Add foam padding Calf Shank rotation Readjust sleeve position, check alignment Ankle Misaligned axis Verify device axis matches ankle axis

docs.title: 5. General Diagnostic Checklist
docs.text:
Before troubleshooting, verify:

  • [ ] All bolts are tightened (but not over-torqued)
  • [ ] Bearings are properly seated
  • [ ] No visible cracks or deformations
  • [ ] Gearbox rotates smoothly by hand
  • [ ] Hinge moves freely
  • [ ] Shoe interface is securely attached
  • [ ] Laces are properly tensioned
  • [ ] Motor is unpowered during inspection

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Troubleshooting — Assembly Issues
  • 3D Printing Guide
  • Assembly Guide

docs.title: 📌 2026-01-17 — Initial Public Release
docs.text:
• Initial public launch of the PrintExo project.
  • Documentation framework initialized.
  • Project website opened.
